sp.speaker: Jaſp.
sp.l: I'le hazzard that, rather then certain Death.
And therefore to ſave one, I'le hide you there.

sp.speaker: Witch.
sp.p: O thou ungrateful Dog, doſt kill me for my Love?

sp.speaker: Jaſp.
sp.l: No muttering, Aunt, dye quietly, and lye as
Quietly; 'tis the greateſt kindneſs you can
Do me: So, now a ready lye clears all I hope.
sp.stage: Runs her through often, then throws her into the hole, ſhe ſhould him, then lyes down and trembles.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: The Officers entring, they all vaniſh'd.

sp.speaker: Jaſp.
sp.p: The laſt is well.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: Where's the Witch? What makes you tremble ſo?

sp.speaker: Jaſp.
sp.p: O, do not take me too, good Devil, do not.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: What ayls the Fellow? Jaſper, don't you know me?

sp.speaker: Jaſp.
sp.p: Alas, is't you, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: Ay, where's the Witch?

sp.speaker: Jaſp.
sp.l: She got upon a fiery Dragons back,
And mounted like a Rocket through the Air,
Leaving me half diſtracted.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: 'Tis ſtrange and wonderful.

sp.speaker: 1. VVatch.
sp.p: Here's two of them.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.l: My Lord Antonio! 'Tis ſtrange to meet you thus
In a ſuſpitious Houſe ſo late in the Evening.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: Riding by the River ſide to take the Air,
My Horſe threw me, which made me ſee
For ſome convenient Houſe to reſt a while,
And met with this, wherein I have ſlept this hour,
And I believe had done ſo longer yet,
Had not your noiſe awak'd me.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.l: My Lord, I've no Commiſſion to enquire
Into Perſons bus'neſs of your eminent Rank;
It is for other Men that I ſearch now,
Some half a ſcore the moſt notorious Rogues
About the Town were ſeen to enter here.
Saw you none ſuch, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: No, on my Honour;
For ſince I enter'd here, no human ſhape
Was ſeen by me, but one Old wither'd Woman;
And where ſhe's gone, I know not.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.l: My Lord, that Woman is the greateſt Cheat
About the Town; the ſimple think her a Witch;
But I can witneſs for her ſhe is none;
My Lord, you'l pardon me, if I ſearch for her.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: With all my heart: Pray find her if you can;
'Twas my misfortune doubled to light here.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.l: It might have prov'd ſo:
Search the Houſe.
I'le tell your Lordſhip what I know of her.
Walking my Round one Night, who ſhould I meet,
But (as I thought) two Devils, by their ſhapes;
An Old one, and a Young one, ſo they ſeem'd:
At firſt the ſight amaz'd me, but at laſt
My Reaſon telling me, if they were Spirits,
The miſchief they intended they might do,
Though I ſhould run away: I bid my Guard
Stand, whilſt my ſelf advanc'd near theſe ſhapes,
Which as I did, the little Devil fled, th' other ſeem'd
To turn it's Eyes to fire, and glare upon me;
I ſtill advanc'd, Arm'd with my former thoughts,
And as I nearer came, the fire grew duller,
Yet ſtill it ſtood, for truly it could not run,
Proving, when I laid hold on't, this Old Woman,
Cas'd in a Leopard's skin; the fiery Eyes
Prov'd but two Lobſter-ſhells: So ſhe confeſſing,
That for a Living ſhe did uſe theſe Cheats,
Helping poor People to their ſtolen Goods,
In Devils ſhapes to countenance the Trade.
And that the other was a little Boy,
Train'd up as her Familiar, whom ſhe producing,
I only threaten'd them, and let them go.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: A ſubtle Cheat it was, and very likely,
And you deſerv'd Reward that did detect it.

sp.speaker: Jaſp.
sp.p: A Halter it ſhould be, were I to give it.

div.stage: Enter the Watch with one of the Devils Remarkable Habits, and a Viol.

sp.speaker: 1. Watch.
sp.l: We've ſearch'd ſufficiently, but all we find
Is a poor Devils skin, and a baſe Viol.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.l: I, this is like the other, I'm glad 'twas found,
'Twill prove the ſtory true I told your Lordſhip.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: It does, to my amazement.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.l: I'm glad it was my hap to meet you here,
Your Lordſhip might have got ſome miſchief elſe.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: I might indeed, and I'm beholding to you:
And, Captain, take my word, I'le ſpeak your worth
To the Vice-Roy, who is my Kinſman,
And will take care for to advance your merit.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.l: In that you'l bind my Service: Yet, my Lord,
Shall I not wait your Lordſhip to your Houſe?

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: No, 'twill be wonder'd at, beſides, I've Horſes here.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Then Health and a good Night attend your Lordſhip.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: I thank you, Captain; here, Watch, there's ſome-
Thing for you.

sp.speaker: 1. Watch.
sp.p: Bleſs your Noble Lordſhip.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: Jaſper! Did you hear this?

sp.speaker: Jaſp.
sp.l: Ay, my good Lord, and wonder at it too;
But I do ſtill believe ſhe is a Witch, and only
Did pretend ſuch things to the Captain,
To ſave a Burning from th' Inquiſition.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: Fetch our Horſes.
I do obſerve this Rogue
Strangely to be amaz'd, what er'es the matter;
I do believe that this was all ſome Cheat.
Yet how could that be too, who could Name Lewis.
But I am mad to be deluded thus!
For now I think on't better; in my Paſſion
I hinted Lewis as a proof for all;
And then this Rogue ſtood by — Ay, there it is —
He's a Confederate, and contriv'd all this,
To be Reveng'd, but I'le diſſemble yet,
And trace his miſchiefs further, then I'le kill him,
And ſtop his mouth from publiſhing my folly:
Had not this Accident ſo ſtrangely happen'd,
What miſchief had I done before the Morning:
I'le put him to his Tryal in the Garden,
Which if he fail in, there ſhall end his Life,
And he'l deſerve it too, when miſchiefs tend
To ſuch a height, they muſt in miſchief end.
He that contriv'd ſo many to deſtroy,
Will ſcarce be puniſh'd if he barely dye,
Therefore his Villany ſhall further ſwell,
When'ts at the height I'le Lanch his Soul to hell.

sp.speaker: Sebaſt.
sp.l: Couzen, believe me, I am loath to go,
And I could likewiſe wiſh that you were ſo.
Oft have I fear'd the danger when I went,
Yet dreaded more the ſin then puniſhment.
For I conſider'd, ſhould I then be ſlain,
That Death would but begin an endleſs pain;
Then pardon me, though I could well obey
All Friendſhips Laws, I dare not do't this way.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Sure Couzen, you are ſick, or lately have
Had melancholy thoughts about a Grave:
Is this Sebaſtian, he, whoſe ready hand
Was quick to Act all Friendſhip did Command?
He, who no ſooner heard Franciſco ſay,
A Danger's there, but made that ſtrait his way,
And now he's turn'd my Ghoſtly Father ſure.

sp.speaker: Sebaſt.
sp.l: I would, ſo I might make a Ghoſtly Cure.
Franciſco, thou art ſick, and ſo am I;
Sick at our Souls, and ſhou'd we chance to dye
E're our Diſeaſe was Cur'd, 'tis ten to one,
We ſhould in an Eternal Feaver groan.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Come, prethee ſay no more, 'tis ominous,
I wonder much what 'tis ſhou'd make thee thus.
Come, you muſt go this Night: I'le tell you why,
'Twill be the laſt, for ſhe's to Marry,
To Marry Don Gerardo! O 'tis rate,
I am Reveng'd to th' purpoſe.

sp.speaker: Sebaſt.
sp.l: Sure you are
Turn'd Coward, or you ne're wou'd glory in
Revenge ſo baſe, this doubles all your ſin.
Gerardo's brave, and ſure all Honour bleeds,
When ſuch are Wounded by Ignoble deeds.
It is the Curſe of Man, that he muſt be
Subject to ſhame by Womens Levity;
But hold, I wrong Eugenia, if I blame
Her, and not you alone, for all her ſhame.
You Rob'd her of her Chaſtity by force,
Though fear of ſhame ſtill kept her from Remorſe.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Piſh! Force! That was her policy to you,
She did no more then what all Women do,
Seem to reſiſt what they do moſt deſire,
To raiſe the flame, yet ſeem to cool the fire;
Believe this Truth, Sebaſtian, Women can
Reſiſt it, and perform it more then Man.

sp.speaker: Sebaſt.
sp.l: Thus like the Devils we at firſt betray
Their Innocence, then blame on them we lay;
As if their guilt cou'd have another cauſe
Then that which it from our Temptation draws.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Let it be ſo, I'le not diſpute it now;
It grows too near the time that I ſhould go,
And though my Actions do ſo much offend,
I will not doubt to find another Friend.

sp.speaker: Sebaſt.
sp.l: Do you ſo little prize Eugenia's Fame,
That you can ſuffer more to know her ſhame?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Sebaſtian, you miſtake, I do not go
This Night on the ſame terms I us'd to do.
No, 'tis to take my leave, for ſhe does vow
In ſpight of fear ſhe is turn'd vertuous now.

sp.speaker: Sebaſt.
sp.l: Nay, then I'le go my ſelf, happen what will,
For it is only dang'rous to do ill;
My Company her Vertue may protect,
And I ſhould ſin, if that I did neglect.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: That ſhall not need, for I'm reſolv'd to ſpeak
Nothing that may her Reſolution break.

sp.speaker: Sebaſt.
sp.l: Go boldly then, for in a cauſe ſo good
He's more then Coward fears to ſhed his Blood;
And though I think Antonio would be glad
That he our Lives at ſuch advantage had;
Yet I this Night durſt boldly meet him there,
Since in my Breaſt ſuch Innocence I wear;
By this ſecurity I plainly feel
'Tis guilt that wounds us deeper far then ſteel.

sp.speaker: Cael.
sp.l: Blame not my Husband, Siſter, 'twas my fault,
I ſtrove 'gainſt Reaſon to oppoſe his Will.
Had I forborn my importunity,
'Tis ten to one he had not been ſo wilful;
Husband's prerogatives are abſolute,
Their wills we muſt obey, and not diſpute.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: I beg his Pardon, if I think amiſs,
But I believe there's ſome deſign in this;
His Eyes ſhew'd more of Anger then could be
A bare concern for's Friend's Infirmity.

sp.speaker: Cael.
sp.l: I will no cenſure on his Actions lay,
My Duty is for their ſucceſs to pray.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Your Servant, Ladies, where is Don Antonio?

sp.speaker: Cael.
sp.p: Why, at Don Johns, my Lord, do not you know it?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Then he is not come back, as I had thought.

sp.speaker: Cael.
sp.p: My Lord, why thought you ſo?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Madam, I did not know but that he might,
Since 'tis not five hours bus'neſs to Ride thither,
And to return again; but, Madam, pray
How came the Lord Franciſco to be here?
I think he does not uſe it.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Franciſco! O my fears!

sp.speaker: Cael.
sp.l: No ſure, my Lord, he ne're came within theſe doors
Since my good Father dy'd.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Sure I'm miſtaken, Madam, if I did not
Meet him juſt now as he came forth this Room:
And more, he ſhak'd his head in Anger at me.

sp.speaker: Cael.
sp.l: I'm ſure, my Lord, you're miſtaken much,
For you're the firſt that enter'd here but us.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: It may be I'm miſtaken.

sp.speaker: Cael.
sp.p: Yes, ſure, my Lord, you are.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Madam, if your Commands
Extend to any thing within my pow'r, pray name it,
I ſhall be proud to ſerve you; elſe I'm gone,
For I have certain bus'neſs does require it.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: The greateſt Service you can do to me,
Is to be careful of your ſelf, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: This kindneſs doth oblige me, pardon my haſte,
Good Night, and Reſt unto your Ladyſhips.

sp.speaker: Cael.
sp.l: Good Night, my Lord;
Flora is ſo poſſeſt her Dream is true,
She dare not venture in that Room again.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: She is not ſuch a Fool, ſure.

sp.speaker: Cael.
sp.l: Well, Siſter, I am not well, and will to Bed;
The Nurſe will wait on you, I'le ſend her to you.
Come, Flora, go with me.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Madam, good Reſt unto you.
This I can wiſh to her, whilſt I muſt want it:
Gerardo ſure has ſome Intelligence
Of Don Franciſco's coming to me;
Or elſe why Nam'd he him, for well he knows
He never us'd to make a Viſit here:
Well, if he does, I cannot help it now.
The time draws nigh,
That I muſt meet Franciſco! Oh, that word
Gives heavineſs a new unto my Soul,
And makes my thoughts run backwards,
The Accidents oth' day ſeems Ominous
To all the Houſe, but moſt of all to me,
My guilty Breaſt feels moſt of miſery.
This time will quickly over, then I ſhall
See what they tend to, or not ſee at all.
"There's comfort yet, that miſeries at height
"Loſe their firſt property, which is to fright.

p.hi: The End of the Third Act.

div.head: Act the Fourth.
div.stage: Caelia on a Couch, Flora by her.

sp.speaker: Cael.
sp.l: FLora, I cannot ſleep, for all my thoughts
Infected with my griefs, flye up and down,
Collecting only things to keep me waking.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: I'le not ſtir from you, Madam, 'all this Night.

sp.speaker: Cael.
sp.l: Flora, thy diligence deſerves Reward,
And I'le not long be backward for to thank thee.
But prethee ſing that Song I love ſo well,
That harmony, perhaps, will Charm my cares,
And give my ſenſes Reſt.

lg.head: The Song.
lg.l: AH, Choridon, in vain you boaſt,
You ſtill do Cloris Love;
For better 'tis your heart were loſt,
Then thus ſuſpitious prove:
You then would kill me by diſdain,
But dying thus you blot my Name.
For all will ſay
Cloris was falſe, and went aſtray;
Cloris was falſe, and did deſerve her ſhame.
For happy Shepherd, well you know,
Your Fame does mine excell;
All Gen'rous Choridons do know,
But none my Tale can tell:
Cloris, though true, muſt loſe that Name,
But Choridon will keep his Fame;
For all will ſay
Cloris was falſe, and went aſtray,
Cloris was falſe, and did deſerve her ſhame.
But Cruel Shepherd, when you hear
That I am dead indeed,
I do believe you'l ſhed a tear,
Though now you have decreed,
That Cloris true muſt loſe that Name,
For Choridon to keep his Fame;
And then you'l ſay
Cloris was true, and ne're did ſtray;
Cloris was true, and I deſerve her ſhame.

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.l: She's faln aſleep, may none but happy Dreams
Poſſeſs her Fancy.

div.stage: Enter Antonio and Jaſper in the Garden.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: Your confidence in this doth much amaze me.

sp.speaker: Jaſp.
sp.l: Sir, ſtill I'le pawn my Life, that what I ſaid,
Appears e're long a truth Infallible,
And your own Eyes will bear me witneſs of it.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: Well, pitch upon a private ſtand for us,
That you know moſt convenient.
Strange it is,
If this ſhould prove a falſhood after this;
I've threaten'd him with Death upon the failer,
Yet ſtill he has perſiſted to affirm it,
Beſides, I climb'd the Garden Wall before him,
And that way gave him time for his eſcape,
If he'd deſign to make it: Theſe Circumſtances
Do half perſwade 'tis true. Oh, apprehenſion!
So terrible the conſequence appears,
It makes my brain turn round, and Night ſeem darker.
The Moon begins to drown her ſelf in Clouds,
Leaving a duskiſh horror every where,
My ſickly fancy makes the Garden ſeem
Like thoſe benighted Groves in Pluto's Kingdoms,
Which Poets fancy that the damn'd Inhabit.

sp.speaker: Jaſp.
sp.p: My Lord, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: What now?

sp.speaker: Jaſp.
sp.l: The Garden Door juſt opens, ſtep this way, leſt
You be ſeen.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: 'Tis hardly late enough, we'l ſtay a little,
For I perceive no light i'th' uſual Window.

sp.speaker: Sebaſt,
sp.p: But are you confident Antonio's abſent?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: I'm told for certain that he went from home
To ſee Don John Valaſco, who is ſick.

sp.speaker: Sebaſt.
sp.l: Nay, then with ſafety we may walk a turn,
Though I confeſs, do what I can, my fears
Surmount my Reaſon, and perſwades there's danger.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: A hundred times I've paſt it in as much,
Yet then with confidence you ſlighted all;
Prethee forbear to urge them any more;
I'm half turn'd Coward with your fears already.

sp.speaker: Sebaſt.
sp.l: Let's take a turn then further from the Houſe,
And by ſome other talk divert our thoughts.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: Jaſper, I find thy Informations true,
Thus far at leaſt; theſe are my Wife's kind Couzens.
Hell rid e'm from the World.

sp.speaker: Jaſp.
sp.l: A hundred times they had been here before
In as much danger: Mark you that, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: I, and his Soul retorted back the Lye,
For they in all their Lives ne're knew a danger
Equal to that they're near: Heark! how the Owl
Summons their Souls to take a flight with her,
Where they ſhall be Eternally benighted:
Now I again believe it was a Witch;
For here me-thinks I ſee a thouſand Devils
Waiting in the Air with fire-forks in their hands,
Juſt as our City Serjeants wait with Maces,
To toſs their Souls to their Eternal Priſon;
Look there, that flaſh of Lightning does confirm it.
Nay, do but ſtay a little, you ſhall have all.
All, all; not a Soul of e'm ſhall eſcape this Night.
No, no, 'twill ſpoil good Company to part them.
But hold, a Light appears, draw back to cover.

sp.speaker: Sebaſt.
sp.p: The Light is there, make haſte and give the ſign.
sp.stage: Franciſco ſtrikes a Key upon his Sword; Eugenia appears above in Caelia's Gown.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Who's there, Franciſco?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: The ſame, and would deſire your Company below.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: This diſtance fits us better! Oh, Franciſco,
Had we but alwayes kept it, I had been
A ſpotleſs Off'ring to my Bridal Bed,
But now muſt cloud my Marriage Joys with ſhame,
And fear of what will follow.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Pray deſcend, this diſtance is not ſafe,
The Family may chance o're hear our words.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: I've more cauſe, ſhould I come down,
You would attempt my ſtrength, and Argument
To violate my Vows, as firſt you did
My Virgin-Honour.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: No, upon my Life, do but deſcend,
And may the Heav'ns pour all their Vengeance on me
If I do attempt you with a ſillable
To break your Reſolution.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Is any with you?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Yes, my Friend, Sebaſtian.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Let him ſpeak, then.

sp.speaker: Sebaſt.
sp.l: Madam, upon my Life, I will ſecure you,
And glory I have ſo much cauſe to do it.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Your Virtue I rely on for my ſafety.
sp.stage: She takes the Light from above.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: I cannot hear their words, yet I'm ſure
It's Caelia's there, her Habit tells me that.
Let's draw a little nearer.

sp.speaker: Sebaſt.
sp.l: Look there, Franciſco, are not thoſe two Men
Are creeping there?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: 'Tis ſo, let's ſlip aſide.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Where are you, Couzen Franciſco? Are you there?

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: I, here, here, perfidious Woman.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Oh, Franciſco, 'tis an inhuman deed,
To kill me thus, 'cauſe I would ſin no longer,
But thou haſt kept thy word, and took thy leave.
As I muſt now, of all the World, and thee — oh, oh —

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Pray Heav'n I be'n't too late, the Garden door
So open makes me wonder: Heard you no groans?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: I think I did, my Lord; heark, Sir again.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Oh, oh; I fain would live a little longer,
If but to ask forgiveneſs of Gerardo,
My Soul will ſcarce reach Heav'n without his Pardon.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Who's that wou'd go to Heav'n, and wants my Pardon?
Take it, what e're thou art, and mayſt thou be
Happy in Death, what e're thou didſt deſign.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Is that Gerardo's Voyce? Sure loſs of Blood
Doth make my fancy Idle: Is't Gerardo?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Thou greateſt Bleſſing of my Soul, it is.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: No, no, my Lord, you will abhor my Name,
When I ſhall tell the ſtory made me thus.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Heav'n knows I ſooner ſhould abhor my Life:
But tell me the Author of this horrid miſchief,
That I may flye as quick to my Revenge,
As theſe ſad thoughts do ſeize upon thy Soul.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: When you ſhall hear my ſtory, your Revenge
Will, as I fear, vent againſt me in Curſes.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Were thy Crimes great as theirs that left thee thus,
By all thy Virgin hopes I would not Curſe thee.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: My Lord, that's it you are deceiv'd in.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Nay, now thou rav'ſt — help me to bend her body
Her loſs of Blood will keep her ſtory from me;
And I ſhall Live i'th' dark, and ne're Revenge her.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Alas, my Lord, my Couzen, baſe Franciſco,
Being let in by my accurſed Nurſe,
Came to my bed, and there by force and ſtrength obtain'd
His hated ends.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Oh, damn'd Villain, he ſhall not long ſurvive
To boaſt of it.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Had I ſtaid there, and not conſented further,
I ſhould have needed pity, and not pardon.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Tell all the reſt, for this is ſo ſurprizing,
I'd fain perſwade my ſelf it was a Dream.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: After this Fatal loſs, a ſhame ſucceeded,
Shame that produc'd fear; infus'd by threats
Urg'd both by him and her, wherein they ſaid,
If I refus'd to grant that willingly,
Which he at firſt did force, they would declare
The Action to the World, ſo to diſgrace me.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: O that old wrinkl'd Hag! that ſhe ſhould plot this.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: What will not wicked Age effect for Gold?
But they at laſt made fear or'e-come my Vertue,
And I by that made all their guilt my own,
Meeting him here ſtill when he did appoint.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Well, this confeſt, how came you by theſe Wounds?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: My Lord, Franciſco did entreat my Company
This Night; when as I enter'd,
Without a word, but here, perfidious Woman,
He ſtab'd me in the Breaſt, and left me thus.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Hadſt thou been dead, and Angels told the ſtory,
I ſhould have thought, in Envy of thy worth,
They had invented it, and ne're believ'd it.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: I have no breath to tell you; oh, my Lord,
I do forget, they ſtill are in the Garden —
Have a care of —

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Have a care of what? Oh, ſpeak, Eugenia, ſpeak.
She's gone, ſhe's gone; and could not tell her mind:
What is't I muſt have a care on! O ſome Angel
That waits to ſhew her Soul the way to Heav'n,
Come back and tell me, what it was ſhe meant:
Was it her Reputation ſhe took care of?
No, no, that cannot be, had it been that,
She might have kept the ſtory to her ſelf:
And there been Canoniz'd: Was it of me
She did expreſs her care? If ſo, 'twas needleſs;
For he that lets me Live to kill Franciſco,
Though he does ſo by me, when that is done,
Shall have my thanks and Prayers i'th' other World;
But ſtay, they're in the Garden, I'le go look e'm,
"For if Revenge ſo juſt I do delay,
"I ſhall deſerve Heav'ns Vengeance for the ſtay.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Who ſhould they be I wonder talk'd ſo long?

sp.speaker: Sebaſt.
sp.l: Sure, when ſhe found us not, ſhe would retire.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: No doubt on't; yet I am not ſatisfy'd what two
Thoſe were, and why they ſtaid ſo long.
Could your Ear reach to underſtand their words?

sp.speaker: Sebaſt.
sp.l: No, not a ſyllable more then a humming noiſe.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Nor mine; but now they're gone, let's walk that way,
'Twill be the beſt to miſs them.

sp.speaker: Sebaſt.
sp.l: Content.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: It is in vain to look e'm if they hide,
The Garden's large; beſides perhaps they're gone;
We'l to the Body.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: You're by it now, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: This Accident amazes me ſo much,
I go I know not where.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: See there, my Lord, two Men.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: W'are pretty near the Window, there's no Light.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Have at thy heart, Franciſco,
This Token from Eugenia.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Nay, then, at thine: Be whom thou wilt, that Name
Tells me thou'rt no Friend.
sp.stage: They Fight, the Servant ſhoots Sebaſtian juſt as Franciſco ruas Gerardo through, which purſuing, Servant kills him too.

sp.speaker: Sebaſt.
sp.l: Courage, Sebaſtian's by thee.
My fears are come about, for I am kill'd;
Franciſco, fare thee well.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: 'Tis double Death to ſee my Friend dye thus.
Was't not enough, you Fates, to take my Life,
But I muſt guilty be of murd'ring him.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: My Lord, how do you?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Making what haſte I can to meet Eugenia.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: O me! Unfortunate!

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Bewail me not; Death is a pleaſure to me,
Since I can ſee Franciſco lye there by me;
But ask him e're I dye,
What made him kill Eugenia?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: What, is Eugenia Dead?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Why ſeems it ſtrange to thee, who baſely haſt
Firſt Rob'd her of her Honour, then of Life.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Gerardo, it was cruelty to kill her, being as
Yet ſhe had not done thee wrong, and dying,
I rejoyce I have Reveng'd her.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Franciſco, ſure thy Crimes have made thee Devil,
Or thou would'ſt ne're transfer thy Treachery
By murd'ring her, and place it thus on me.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: May I reach Heav'n as I'm Innocent
Of any Death but yours: Which if a guilt
Forgive me Heav'n and you as —

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: He's dead, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: With ſuch a Lye in's mouth;
O Heavenly Angels lead me not this way,
For he muſt alwayes walk i'th' paths of falſhood;
Remove me nearer to Eugenia's Body;
My Spirits faint apace, and I muſt follow:
One word, and then farewell;
I have no time for to Reward thy care:
Here, take this Ring, and give it to my Brother,
He left it with me when he went to Travel;
Tell him I ſtill preſerv'd it for his ſake,
A faithful pledge of our United Friendſhip.
Bid him, that by this Token he believes
Three words I left within my Cabinet
Concerning thee this Evening: He will do it,
And uſe thee as a Friend, as I have done.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: I'le bear the Ring, but not the Meſſage, Sir;
I ne're will ſeek for Friends when you are gone.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: I do conjure thee do it: Tell our ſtory too
As true as is thy ſelf: But have a care,
Wound not Eugenia's Fame more then muſt needs.
Franciſco's and Eugenia's dying words
Will make it ſtrangely dark, as 'tis to me,
But I muſt leave it ſo!
Give me thy hand, commend me to Antonio;
Alas! I had forgot him, pray Heav'n his ſtory
Produce no further miſchief; tell Caelia nothing
Befor't be day: Bus'neſs comes thronging on me,
But I faint — make but one Grave, and lay us
In it thus — Farewell.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: Now dyes the juſteſt Man the Earth contains,
And I would do ſo too, but that I know
Self-murderers ne're muſt keep him Company;
I'le ſet the Bodies up againſt the Wall,
And call the Watch; what if they ſay I'm guilty,
And make my Life to anſwer all theſe Deaths:
Why, let e'm do't, for Death would now be well
Since to ſurvive his loſs to me's a Hell.

sp.speaker: Jaſp.
sp.l: Come, come, my Lord, the coaſt is quiet now.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: I hope that Piſtol ſav'd our ſwords a labour.

sp.speaker: Jaſp.
sp.l: I'm ſure they could not leave the Garden yet,
But we muſt needs have ſeem e'm.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: Nay, I'm ſure they did not paſs the Garden door,
For if they had, we ſhould have ſtopt their Journey.

sp.speaker: Jaſp.
sp.l: I think I heard a talking up this way,
After the Piſtol made us leave our Poſt.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: Though I did leave the Door, yet ſtill my Eye
Was bent that way, and I ſaw none to paſs.
But ſtay, where's Caelia's Body?

sp.speaker: Jaſp.
sp.l: See, my Lord,
There is a Man doth hold her in his Arms.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: It is Franciſco ſure! Have at his heart.
How's this, not ſtir! Nay, then he's dead
Already — the Moon deceives me, or it is Gerardo.
Oh Heav'n's! It is my Friend, dead, dead, and ſtiff,
And my accurſed hand hath Wounded him.
This is not Caelia neither, but Eugenia in her Gown!
What ſtrange miſtakes are theſe?

sp.speaker: Jaſp.
sp.l: But who are here?

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: What, more!
By Heav'ns Franciſco and his Friend Sebaſtian!
Both dead too! Death has had a Feaſt to Night.
Do not we Dream? As for this Womans Death,
Surely her Fathers Soul did guide my hand
To ſtrike the blow, ſince needs ſhe muſt betray
Her Honour to Franciſco, in theſe meetings!
But oh, my Sword hath pierc'd my Friend Gerardo.
What Fatal Accident mixt his Blood with theirs.
But ſtay, there's Light appears, ſlip into the Grotto.

div.stage: Enter Servant, Captain, and Watch, with two Torches.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: Here is the diſmal place I told you of,
And here the Bodies.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.l: A ſight moſt terrible in time of Peace!
But did Franciſco ſtill deny her Death?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: To his laſt moment;
He did confeſs he had abus'd her,
But would have plac'd her Death upon my Lord.
And ſeem'd as much to wonder we deny'd it
As we that he did ſo.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.l: What ſaid Sebaſtian?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: He ſcarce did ſpeak a word after I ſhot him.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.l: Had we not beſt to knock, and call Antonio?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: He's not at Home.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.l: Yes, but I'm ſure he is.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: He was not late at Night, for I was there.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.l: That's ſtrange, for juſt at ſhutting in o'th' Evening
I met him at a Houſe that ſtands i'th' Suburbs,
Saying, he would go Home.
I think however we had beſt to knock.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: My dying Lord made it his laſt deſire,
That Caelia might not be diſturb'd this Night.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.l: Well, take the Bodies up, and keep e'm ſafe,
You ſhall to the Vice-Roy's preſently with me,
I ſcarce perform my truſt, if I detain
The knowledge of ſo ſtrange an Accident
A moment from his Ears, whoſe Wiſdom will
Direct in this, which far exceeds my skill.

sp.speaker: Jaſp.
sp.l: You ſee, my Lord, that I was in the right,
I only ſaid, it was my Ladies Gown,
But never did affirm it was her Perſon.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: And I am glad it is not: Now, if Nurſe
Fails too in her diſcovery, I am ſafe;
For if we keep our Councel, all theſe Deaths
Lye pat amongſt themſelves, and there's not one,
Except Gerardo, that I'd wiſh alive;
He was my friend, and it looks Ominous,
That I ſhould Wound him ſo, though after Death:
Jaſper, thy diligence ſhan't want Reward,
But that muſt follow: Come, let's away.

sp.speaker: Jaſp.
sp.l: My Reward follows! I believe it does;
'Faith, my good Lord, be ſure it be a good one,
Or be content to hang for Company;
Now hap what will, I'le rid him with this murther;
Till I do make him ſpend's Eſtate to Bribe me:
"I was his Slave before for fear; but now
"I'le make him mine, ſince I this ſecret know.

p.hi: The End of the Fourth Act.

div.head: Act the Fifth.
div.stage: Caelia Diſcover'd in Bed, Flora by her.

sp.speaker: Cael.
sp.l: SUre 'twas a real Piſtol-ſhot that wak'd me,
Yet from a Dream ſo terrible, it did it,
That I had rather never ſleep again,
Then hazzard ſuch another: I thought I ſaw
Lye dead by me,
My Lord Antonio, Don Gerardo, Jaſper,
The Nurſe, Franciſco, and the Young Sebaſtian,
With Pedro, and thy ſelf; this dreadful ſight,
Or elſe the Piſtols noiſe, I ſpoke of, wak'd me,
And made me cry help, help, which frighted thee.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: Why truly, Madam, it was a dreadful Dream,
And I as much was frighted at your call,
Yet, for my own part, I did hear no Piſtol.

sp.speaker: Cael.
sp.l: It may be then, it only was my fancy,
For truly all my Dream ſeems ſtill to me
So like a truth, that I can ſcarce diſtinguiſh
Whether I then did wake, or now am ſleeping;
And but I ſee theſe things, and thee ſo plain,
I ſhould conclude my Dream did ſtill continue.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: Pray Heav'n divert all miſchief from the houſe,
For I have heard it ſaid by Learned Men,
Nay, and Religious too, that Dreams like theſe,
That ſtick ſo faſt upon our fancies waking,
Are guided by a power that's more then Chance,
And alwayes are portents of ſomething like them:
I'm ſure, for my own part, do what I can,
That Dream I had will not yet leave my head,
Which makes me think Jaſper deſigns me miſchief.

sp.speaker: Cael.
sp.l: Flora, you go too far, Dreams are but ſhadows
Reflected from ſome Acts the day preceeding,
As ours are now; for from thoſe Accidents
Of my Lords taking Jaſper, the Dream you told,
And Don Gerardo's naming of Franciſco,
Mine now is formed: Thus they but ſucceed
Things paſt, and not prognoſtick things to come.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: Pray Heav'ns theſe do not do't, but I'm afraid.

div.stage: Enter Nurſe, frighted with Eugenia's Ghoſt.

sp.speaker: Nurſe.
sp.l: Stand off, ſtand off, what makes you follow me?
I'm ſure I did not kill you, if you're dead,
Or if you be not, why are you ſo pale?—
So, ſo — ſhe's gone — but what made me come hither.

sp.speaker: Cael.
sp.l: What, do you ſtudy wayes to fright me, Nurſe?
It is no proper time to play your tricks.
What makes you up at ſuch a time of Night?
Look, how ſhe ſtands amaz'd, and doth not anſwer;
Think you I take a pleaſure to be frighted?
That you perſiſt in't ſtill?

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: What, is the Woman mad, or would be thought ſo?
What makes you ſtand and ſtare thus?

sp.speaker: Nurſe.
sp.l: Did you ſee no Body?

sp.speaker: Cael.
sp.l: Who ſhould we ſee but an Old doting fool,
That turn'd a Child again, would Act like one,
And can't find a proper time for't neither.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: What make you up ſo late, Nurſe?

sp.speaker: Nurſe.
sp.l: What's that to you? It may be I ſat up
To make my Lady merry with this Jeſt,
But now, forſooth, I'm grown too Old to pleaſe her.
You are her favourite — what, come again?
O, do not ſtare ſo at me!

sp.speaker: Cael.
sp.l: There's ſomething more in this then barely play!
How the Old VVoman ſtar'd? ſure ſhe's run mad!
For ſhame, or ſorrow Jaſper goes away.
Prethee follow her.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: Since you will have me, Madam, I will do't,
Though I dare ſcarcely venture.

sp.speaker: Cael.
sp.l: The greateſt Object pity hath, is Age,
When it returns to Childiſhneſs again,
As this Old Woman doth; and though we ſay,
That Age is Honourable, we only mean,
When Gravity and Wiſdom are its marks,
And not gray hairs, and froward peeviſhneſs,
As ten for one, are known by to be Old,
And though we ſee this true, yet we would all
Prolong our time to that decrepid ſtate,
When nothing but contempt can wait upon us;
How ſtrangely ſin daſtards our very Reaſon,
Making that guide us to deſire known ills
Rather then Joys, that promis'd we deſerve not;
For the beſt Men through ſenſe of guilt do fear
To change for unſeen Joys their troubles here.

sp.speaker: Nurſe.
sp.l: If this Ghoſt follow ſtill, 'twill make me mad;
For ſure it is a Ghoſt it looks ſo pale;
Ay, and Eugenia's Ghoſt, I'm ſure it is;
But who ſhould kill her? May be Don Franciſco!
Oh, there it is again — It's not my fault —
Oh, do not follow me then: What ſhall I do?
See there again, ſhe points unto her Breaſts —
It's gone again, I fear 'twill make me mad —
I'le go to Prayers: But I forget my bus'neſs,
My Lord will come, and I muſt let him in,
And ſhew him what I promis'd, or he'l kill me.
What, come again! Oh, Heav'ns! I'le ſtop my Eyes.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: Nurſe, are you mad?

sp.speaker: Nurſe.
sp.l: No, you would make me ſo! But I deſie thee —
Be gone, thou Spirit, i'th' name of Heav'n, be gone.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: Who ſhould be gone?

sp.speaker: Nurſe.
sp.l: Thou! for thou'rt the Devil. Come not near me.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: My Lady ſent me to you —

sp.speaker: Nurſe.
sp.l: No, no, ſhe did not, for ſhe lov'd me always,
And would not ſend the Devil thus to fright me.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: I am no Devil, Nurſe, look upon me, I'm Flora.

sp.speaker: Nurſe.
sp.l: Ay, where's the Spirit then I ſaw juſt now?

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: There was no worſer Spirit then my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Nurſe.
sp.l: No; 'pray Minx, what makes you follow me?
I'le ſet you back again i'th' Devils Name,
Come you to ſpy my Actions.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: No, Nurſe, my Lady ſent me, don't be angry,
She was afraid that you were running mad.

sp.speaker: Nurſe.
sp.l: I, mad, it may be ſo; now I am Old
I muſt be mad, forſooth; but time has been,
There's ne're a Servant durſt have laught at me,
Nor I'le not take it now, no that I won't,
I'le tear your Eyes out firſt.
sp.stage: She runs after Flora, who ſtill is too quick for her.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: Nay, ſoftly, Nurſe; ſo, ſo; ay, there!

sp.speaker: Nurſe.
sp.l: Where, where? I ſee it now, It's ſtrangely pale!
O, do not fright me ſo; it's gone again.
And now I ſhall have time to follow you;
Nay, now I'le tear thy Eyes out.
sp.stage: As Flora runs away, ſhe falls, Nurſe gets upon her

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: Oh, Nurſe, Nurſe! have mercy on me,
Do not ſcratch me ſo.

sp.speaker: Nurſe.
sp.l: I'le be thy Death, there's nothing ſhall preſerve you.
Ah — are you there again! The Devil, the Devil.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: 'Twas well for me her madneſs work't again,
And made her take a whim to run away,
She would have kill'd me elſe, do what I could;
I'le ſtay no longer, leſt ſhe come again.
I'd not be in her fingers as I was
For all I'm worth.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.l: When I conſider every Circumſtance
Of what you tell, and what I know my ſelf,
I muſt conclude, I ought not to defer
To ſearch Antonio's Houſe: if he's from home,
As you pretend he is: It makes me think
There is ſome ſtrange Intrigue deſign'd by him.
For why ſhould he turn back, as you relate,
And then obſcure himſelf in ſuch a Houſe?
Beſides, he told me, he was ſtrait for Home,
And yet it ſeems he was not, as you ſay.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: It's truth, upon my Life, he was not there
At paſt the hour of Nine.

sp.speaker: Watch.
sp.l: Who comes there!
sp.stage: Enter the little Devil, and runs and skulkes.
sp.l: Captain, the Devil, the Devil!
See where he ſtands?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.l: O'my Conſcience! The Witches little Familiar again!
If you're afraid, let me come, I'm us'd to
Theſe ſort of Devils! Come, come, uncaſe,
sp.stage: It ſputters like a Cat, Captain to him.
sp.l: Uncaſe, young Gameſter, what ſlippery pranck
Are you about now? Don't you remember your
Laſt eſcape, Sirrah?

sp.speaker: Devil.
sp.l: Pray Maſter don't whip me, I'le tell all.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.l: Out with it then; where's the Old Witch, your Miſtreſs?

sp.speaker: Devil.
sp.l: Alas, Captain, ſhe was kill'd to Night when
You brought in the Watch to ſearch our Houſe.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.l: Kill'd, by whom?

sp.speaker: Devil.
sp.l: I know not that, but we were putting a cheat
Upon a Lord there, by contrivance of his Man,
And when you knockt, we ran to our lurking holes
To hide us, but when the Coaſt was clear, we came
Out, and ſeeking for my Miſtreſs, found her dead in one
Of the holes, thruſt through her Body with a Dagger in
Three places.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.l: What cheat was that you put upon the Lord?

sp.speaker: Dev.
sp.l: We Acted like Devils, and in a Song made him
Believe his Wife did Cuckold him.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.l: This was Antonio, whom I met there, Sir.

sp.speaker: Devil.
sp.l: Ay, that's his Name, a mighty furious Man,
He ſaid, he'd kill e'm all before 'twas day.
He made me quake to hear him; I hope now,
Captain, you will let me go.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.l: No, no, you Rogue! If he has done more miſchief
You ſhall be hang'd, except you find your Fellows
That joyn'd i'th' cheat with you to make him Jealous.

sp.speaker: Devil.
sp.l: I'le bring you preſently to them, and ſhew you all
Their holes; they did but ſend me out to watch when
The Coaſt was clear!

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.l: Who, ſay you, ſet you on to this deſign?

sp.speaker: Devil.
sp.l: An ill-look'd Rogue, his Man, the Witches Nephew;
I think they call him Jaſper.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.l: Well, take the Boy, and call ſome of your Fellows,
And there ſurprize them all: I'le not defer
My ſearching to prevent the miſchief
That Don Antonio further may deſign,
For I believe he had a hand in this
Was done i'th' Garden, however the miſtake
Did happen to begin between the Dead.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: Come, Sir, make haſte, for I begin to fear
Some Tragedy is Acted in the Houſe,
For Don Antonio's Rage is alwayes quick,
And they have toucht the ſtring will ſtretch it higheſt.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.l: Come then, let's haſten back.

sp.speaker: Nurſe.
sp.l: Ay, that's his whiſtle, and I muſt obey't.
Why Pedro, Pedro! What, are you dead aſleep?
Pedro, I ſay.

sp.speaker: Pedro within.
sp.l: Who calls?

sp.speaker: Nurſe.
sp.l: Pedro, riſe quickly, my Lady Caelia wants you.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: What can ſhe want me for at ſuch a time?

sp.speaker: Nurſe.
sp.l: I know not, but Flora came, and ſaid you muſt
Come quickly, I think, to Ride to my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: I come, but I'le have a care of your Tricks, Nurſe.

sp.speaker: Nurſe.
sp.l: What tricks? What do you
sp.stage: Enter Pedro in a Night-Gown, with his ſword in's hand.
sp.l: Do with your Sword?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Why, Nurſe, you may have malice, and malice
May ſeek miſchief, which becauſe you are no Witch,
And cannot come through a Key-hole to compaſs,
For ought I know, you call me out to do it — ha!
What whiſtle's that?

sp.speaker: Nurſe.
sp.l: What whiſtle! Are you mad! Go to my Lady.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Still I ſuſpect you.

sp.stage: Enter Nurſe, with Antonio and Jaſper.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: Are they together, Nurſe?

sp.speaker: Nurſe.
sp.l: Yes, my Lord, the more's my ſorrow!

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: Nay then, I ſee the Devils did ſpeak truth;
Franciſco, their kind Couzen, Whor'd them both,
By Heav'ns they took their turns, I ſee it plain!
O that I could invent ſome horrid Death,
And had but time to execute it on them;
But ſince I cannot, plain ſtabbing will do well,
The leſs they've here, the more they'l find in Hell.

sp.speaker: Nurſe.
sp.l: I hope you will not kill your Lady, Sir!

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: Not kill her! But I muſt.

sp.speaker: Nurſe.
sp.l: What have I done? Oh, oh.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: Hold, ſtop your mouth, I'le ſtop it for you elſe,
They'l hear her, and eſcape!
Come, Jaſper, are you ready?

sp.speaker: Jaſp.
sp.l: Yes, my Lord, I follow.

sp.speaker: Nurſe.
sp.l: What have I done, one Murder on another?
I ſee 'twas he that kill'd Eugenia, now,
By's naming Don Franciſco; oh, that Jaſper —
Oh, the Ghoſt again — what ſhall I do?

div.stage: Caelia in Bed, and Flora all Bloody.

sp.speaker: Cael.
sp.l: I'm ſorry that I ſent thee, ſince ſhe's mad,
But would 'twas day, that I might get her lookt to.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: I'm ſure ſhe has ſcratch't my face ſufficiently.

sp.speaker: Cael.
sp.l: 'Tis well it was no worſe.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: Alas! ſhe'l come again!

l.hi: Flora, Flora.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: Who's that, Pedro! What's the matter with you?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Nurſe call'd, and ſaid my Lady would ſpeak with me.

sp.speaker: Cael.
sp.l: Bid him come in.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: My Lady bids you enter.

sp.speaker: Cael.
sp.l: Pedro, the Nurſe is mad, I did not call you,
You ſee how ſhe has ſcratcht poor Flora's Face,
She came juſt now ſhreeking and ſtaring hither;
If you could lock her up into ſome Room,
It would do well.
sp.stage: A noiſe, Exiturus, he fights, and Enters with Antonio, whom when he ſees, he lets fall his point, and is kill'd. Jaſper runs Flora through.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: I hear her coming up.
Thieves, Madam, Thieves!
Oh Heav'ns, it is my Lord!

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: Damn'd Letcher, ſo it is!
What, does your Courage fail you —
There, take that —
And boaſt in Hell that Don Antonio's Sword
Did thee thr Honour to ſend thee thither.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: O Heav'ns! My fears were true, the Rogue has kill'd me.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: Now Monſter of thy Sex, ſee this, and tell me
What are the effects you do expect from it?

sp.speaker: Cael.
sp.l: Death, that's leſs terrible then is your Anger,
Which I perceive by it's effects already,
Upon that Innocent Man cannot ſtay there.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: Are your concerns for him, when they ſhould be
Employ'd to Heav'n for mercy to your Soul?
Nay, then Hell take it's Quarry; this for Don Lewis,
This for Don Franciſco; and take this laſt
For thy inſatiate Luſt with that damn'd Hind.

sp.speaker: Cael.
sp.l: This killing me, my Lord, is very cruel;
Since I ne're ſinn'd in thought againſt your Honour.
This, as I do expect Eternal Reſt,
Is ſuch a Truth, that I can dye in it.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: O Hell and Furies! This Womans impudence exceeds you all.
See there a Dog juſt wreeking from thy Bed,
Hot with the Labour you have put him to
And yet in thought you did not wrong my Honour.

sp.speaker: Cael.
sp.l: From my Bed, my Lord! You are abus'd;
That fellow was not here full half a minute,
E're your ſelf enter'd! Oh, I can no more —
Heav'n and the World grant Pardon for my Blood.
For truth it ſelf bears witneſs; I dare ſay
That more I ſorrow for your guilt then Death.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: If this be true, tell me as thou art dying,
What made him here at ſuch a time o' Night?

sp.speaker: Cael.
sp.l: I cannot tell more, then that the Nurſe did ſend him;
And ſhe's run mad with guilt, or ſhame, or both!
Oh, I can ſay no more — the Room turns Round;
My Lord, farewell — Heav'n pardon you all Blood,
As I forgive you mine — oh, oh, —

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: Her Death both ſtaggers, and amazes me!
Are theſe Dead too?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Not yet, my Lord, I am not.
Your Sword hath left me ſome ſmall time for Prayers,
And it had need; for I believe few Souls
Can be aſſur'd to find their way to heav'n
Without more warning to begin their Journey.
But yet I do not find much cauſe for doubt.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: Nay, if thou'ſt hopes, by that I do conjure thee
Tell me, what brought thee hither?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: The Nurſes madneſs;
She call'd me from my Bed, and told me, Flora
Was ſent to bid me come unto my Lady,
Which though I ſcarce believ'd, yet I did do't.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: VVhy did you ſay it was her madneſs did it?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: My Lady ſaid ſhe was ſo, for ſhe came
Not long before ſhreeking into this Chamber,
So as you enter'd I was going down
To lock her up till morning in ſome Room:
This, as I hope for heav'n, my Lord, is true.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: Then 'tis as true, that I muſt never hope for it.
For I have kill'd a VVife of ſuch obedience —
But hold, I'le pump the Nurſe — who ſet her on
To tell me this.

sp.speaker: Nurſe.
sp.l: O! whether will you drive me!
Be gone, be gone!

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: Here, here ſhe comes, I'le make her tell me all.

sp.speaker: Jaſp.
sp.l: But I'le prevent the ſtory if I can. —
sp.stage: Jaſper Runs Nurſe through but is ſtaid by Antonio.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: What, does the Villain mean to kill her yet?

sp.speaker: Jaſp.
sp.l: Does ſhe not deſerve it? To invent ſuch lyes,
And do ſuch miſchiefs with them.

sp.speaker: Nurſe.
sp.l: O thou damn'd Rogue! 'Twas thou that made me do't.

sp.speaker: Jaſp.
sp.l: You lying VVitch, be damn'd —

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: Forbear, you Rogue, I'le do as much for you elſe.
Speak, why you did it?

sp.speaker: Nurſe.
sp.l: My Lord, he threaten'd me, and made me do't;
And taught me to call Pedro when you knockt.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Look to your ſelf, my Lord, he'l kill you elſe.

sp.speaker: Jaſp.
sp.l: This way is only left — hell take your Tongue.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: Ah, thou haſt kill'd me; yet I have ſtrength enough
To ſend thy Soul to hell.
sp.stage: They fight. A noiſe without. Jaſper is mortally wounded.

sp.speaker: Jaſp.
sp.l: 'Tis done, I am catch'd at laſt in my
Own Trap. Oh, I deſerve my Death for want
Of fore-ſight, to let him Live a ſpye upon my Actions.
I ſhould have ſerv'd you thus, and thus,
sp.stage: Runs Pedro through as he lyes, and Nurſe.
sp.l: And thus — and you too thus.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Oh, O, O!

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: Infernal Monſter! how his malice laſts.

sp.speaker: Within.
sp.l: This way's the noiſe.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.l: VVhat horrid ſight is this? VVe come too late.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: Too late indeed, except you'd come to ſave
The beſt of VVives that there lyes murder'd
By my accurſed hand.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.l: VVhat, Caelia dead too! VVhat made you do't, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Jaſp.
sp.l: Alas! he cannot tell; the Jealous fool
VVas but an Inſtrument in my Revenge;
'Tis only I can tell you why ſhe dy'd.
But yet I would not give that ſatisfaction,
Did I not fear my Name would be forgotten,
Except this Tale of my Revenge was known;
In which I ſhall live famous. —

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: O thou Dogg! Doſt glory in the miſcheifs thou haſt done?

sp.speaker: Jaſp.
sp.l: I, and have reaſon; name the man that ever
Did in one Day contrive ſo many Murders,
And make 'em all Succeſsful.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.l: But what ſhould move thee to this Villainy?

sp.speaker: Jaſp.
sp.l: For that you will not wonder.
I am Jaſper De Monſalvo, Heir to that Eſtate
This Lord doth now poſſeſs.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: Ah Heav'ns! ſome of that deſperate Bandity
Did once attempt my life.

sp.speaker: Jaſp.
sp.l: Yes truly —

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: Poor Caelia, 'tis no wonder thy mind did boad
Great miſciefs from this Fellow, being Son of
One did ſtill contrive to kill me, for what the
King after juſt forfeiture for mighty ſervices
Had given my Father.

sp.speaker: Jaſp.
sp.l: O Revenge!
Thy ſweetneſs takes away the taſte of Death.
But you'l loſe my ſtory; which in ſhort is this:
That Lady lov'd me not, and therefore I
Made her Lord Jealous, took him to a Witch,
And there I fool'd him finely: Till the Jade,
Who was my Aunt in deed, at your approach
Would have diſcover'd all; which I prevented,
And ſtopt her Mouth with this: Then I contriv'd
To kill Eugenia, knowing ſhe would meet
Franciſco in the Garden; that I did
Becauſe ſhe call'd me Villain, and refus'd
To lent me Whore her too, as did her Couzen;
And more, I knew the ſimple Lord I ſerv'd
When he had Murder'd her, as I ſhould make him,
Would thank my Care, and well reward it too:
Nay, I'd have him do't for his own ſafety,
That ſtill the Murder might be thought Franciſco's;
You know the reſt i'th' Garden. I taught beſides
That damn'd Old Hagg, whoſe fear has made me thus,
To put this trick on Pedro: I bid her call him
When ſhe ſhould hear us whiſtle, then in haſte,
And all undreſt ſend him to Caelia's Chamber,
Whilſt we, let in, might meet him coming thence,
Thinking the Cuckold's Rage would murder all,
And never hear 'em ſpeak; but there I fail'd,
Their dying words betray'd me, that's the worſt,
Or I had liv'd to glory in their Deaths;
But this my Comfort is, he'l not ſurvive me,
I have done his bus'neſs too before I dye.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: Was er'e ſo Impudent a Villain ſeen?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.l: I'le try to ſtop his wounds, that ſo
I may keep him for Execution.

sp.speaker: Jaſp.
sp.l: Stand off, by Hell,
He that comes near me finds his Death with this!
Think you I'm grown ſo tame to dye by Law;
No, no, I'le not endure a formal Tryal,
To be upbraided with thoſe things I think
Deſerve a Trophy rather then Contempt,
Which ſince I know will follow, here's my Bail,
This will deliver any man from Jayl.
Let Cowards dye by hanging; ſuch as I
As we live bravely, thus dare bravely dye.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.l: He has done well; no Excutioner
Could have been found ſo bad as his own hand,
And Hell will give him what he wants on Earth:
And yet, my Lord, it troubles me for you,
Since my Place binds me to ſecure your Perſon,
To anſwer Law for all your Rage has done.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: Shame almoſt ſtops my mouth; yet, Captain, know
My wound won't give me time for that misfortune;
Stay but a little, let me fix my Eyes
On what lies here, for that alone would give me
A ſudden Death, had I no other hurt.
I dare not hope for Heav'n, having done
So black a Murder on ſuch Innocence,
And yet I do believe her Charity
As it did dying, ſtill doth beg that Pardon
Might from above be granted to my ſoul,
Which if I miſs, as I have cauſe to fear,
Then ſure I ſhall be turn'd into a Devil
For ever to Torment his Curſed ſoul
That led me to theſe miſchiefs.
'Twould be ſome eaſe, if Heaven but granted that,
But I begin to faint! Oh, Bleſſed Soul
Dart forth one Beam of Light, to guide the way,
Or I ſhall always wander in the dark.
Night ſeizes me already: yet from hence
In ſpight of death my ſoul ſhall take her flight,
Go where I will, I thus ſet out a right.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: Hes dead —

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.l: By dying ſo, at leaſt he's thus far happy,
That he Eſcapes the Puniſhments of Tryal,
And the Exemplar death muſt have attended
Which to a man ſo Jealous of his Fame
As he was, would have been a Hell on Earth.
Your Duty to your Lord will keep you ſafe,
Yet you muſt to the Vice-Roy go with me
To be a Witneſs there of what hath happn'd,
The ſtory elſe will ſeem Incredible.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: I am ready, Sir, for all you ſhall Command.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.l: Oh Jealouſie, thou ſickneſs of great ſouls,
To what a Rage didſt thou tranſport this Lord?
For had his Wife been falſe it was not good
By Murd'ring her to drown himſelf in Blood;

l.hi: For Luſt may be Excus'd ſince fleſh is frail,
But Murder on the Soul does guilt Entail.

lg.l: A Tragedy, and not Heroick Verſe,
The Comick part fit only for Farſe;
No Atheiſm, nor any man we know
Abus'd, no repartee, nor ſplendid ſhow;
But very little Bawdy, and leſs wit,
The Devil's in't, crys one, if this Play hit.
Faith— may be not, and may be too it will,
For Chance ſometimes exceeds all rules of skill.
As he who Rageing did his Pencil throw,
And Painted that by chance, he could not draw
For we have ſeen, and lately too, a Play
Cry'd down by thoſe that cannot keep away
And when they come ſpight of themſelves they ſtay.
And to our ſorrow we have others known,
That for their wit have Wit it ſelf out-done,
And yet you wits, that praiſe 'em ſeldom come.
So the Goodman, oft-times for cauſe unknown,
Leaves well-dreſt Beauteous Wife for Homely Joan.
And you that Miſſes keep too, I'm afraid
Do ſometimes make e'm Jealous of the Maid;
So if this Play not dreſt by rules of Art
Should with ſome Trick of Nature catch the heart;
We'd give you leave to rail, and never fear,
Becauſe we're ſure you'd come to do it here.
Gallants you ſee what e're you ſay or do,
Plays will be writ, and we ſhall Act 'em too.
Some will for pleaſure, ſome for profit write,
Some for Applauſe, and ſome will do't in ſpight,
Such bit by Critticks, ſtrait run mad and bite.
This does our bu'sneſs: but we'd have you know,
VVe wiſh we'd none but true brisk wit to ſhow,
VVe ſilence wiſh that Men might hear a Play,
And wiſh that Vizard Mask would keep away:
But we as well might wiſh we were thoſe Kings
VVe ſometimes Act, as hope to ſee theſe things.
Then ſince to rail o'th' Stage and in the Pit,
Muſt in this ſickly Age be counted VVit;
And that th' Infection connot be ſubdu'd,
VVe Actors for our own ſakes do conclude,
The Itch to write and rail will ne're be cur'd,
And therefore faith let'em be both Endur'd.

div.head: ERRATA.
div.p: PAge 17. Line 36. For your read their. p. 23. l. 19. f. Taylors r. Juglers. p. 31. l. 18. r. my fears. p. 38. l. 7. r. Villain by. p. 51. l. 6. f. firſt r. worſt. p. 53. l. 35. f. his r. in. p. 57. l. 11. f. there r. then. p. 58. l. 36. f. this r. his.
